div.p: 1. IV:30— Wednesday. Went to Boston early this morning— Met Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and Mr Ward, the Treasurer of Harvard University, at the Life Insurance Office in State Street. Mr Quincy the President of the University, and Mr Bowditch a member of the Corporation were also there— Mr W. N. Boylston had given two bonds to the President and fellows of Harvard College, which his Executors wished to discharge and cancel— One for one thousand dollars conditioned for the annual payment of fifty dollars, for the elocution prizes— The bond was on its face for 1200 dollars—but it reserved the right of rescinding the grant within three years, and was to be void on the grantors providing by his Will for the payment by his Executors of 1000 dollars, which provision he accordingly made. Although the bond stipulated for the payment of 50 dollars a year, Mr Boylston while he lived did actually pay sixty—and the same sum has been paid by his Executors since his decease. Those payments had been made, till the last Commencement— The bond was now paid, with interest to this day, and taken up, with a receipt signed by Mr Ward, entered upon it— The other bond was for 1500 dollars, conditioned for the payment of 100 dollars a year, for the medical prizes: and with this there is a mortgage of part of Mr Boylston’s real Estate in Roxbury. Mr Bowditch thought that these instruments should not be cancelled unless by a formal vote of the Corporation— The whole penalty of the bond, not being equivalent to the annuity of 100 dollars. He said that money to a very large amount might now be obtained at 4 per Cent annual interest— We were obliged therefore to leave this bond and mortgage uncancelled— President Quincy promised to meet me, rain or shine, next Tuesday at the Probate Court in Dedham; to settle an Executors account, in the Execution of my father’s Will— Returning to Charles’s Office, I next provided myself with a pair of India rubber shoes, and a wadded wrapper, for my projected Journey to Washington. Dined with Charles at Dr. George Parkman’s—Mr Lemuel Shaw, now Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth—R. G. Shaw—Francis and Daniel Parkman; the two young Coolidge’s—D. Davis Solicitor General, and Mr Palfrey was there & Judge P. Thacher. We retired early; and Charles and his wife came out with me to Quincy—

2. V:30. Thursday— Thanksgiving day— Heard Mr Peter Whitney, from 1. Corinthians 4.7. “For who maketh thee to differ from another?” The text is susceptible of great variety of comment, but Mr Whitney presented it as subject of Thanksgiving to the supreme disposer that he had made us to differ from other Nations in our Circumstances, and our Fortunes— He pointed out the happy condition of the people of this Country, which is perhaps as real, as can belong to the state of man upon Earth; and of which none of us are duly sensible— Other nations however have their enjoyments, and might perhaps thank God, as sincerely for having made them differ from us, as we can for differing from them— The happiness of the Romans consisted in War, Liberty, and perpetual civil contention— There are Nations now, which can never be satisfied with tranquility— Europe is upon the verge
verge of bloody and long convulsions in search of happiness, which I fear we shall lose sooner than she will find— To thank God because we are not like other men is a practice not commended to imitation in the gospel— This usage of commemorating by a yearly religious festival the goodness of God, for his blessings bestowed in the course of the year, is wise in itself, and something more than a substitute for Christmas, which with the other Romish Church festivals our puritan ancestors discarded— The general motives for Thanksgiving to God, are—health—a fruitful Season—Peace; and contented minds.— A due sense of the goodness of God, is itself among the greatest blessings that he bestows— This day was clear and cold— Mr Price Greenleaf called and took charge of any of my plants in flower-pots and Tumblers— I promised to send him one of those, where my white Oak Acorns are growing— Charles and his wife, mine and myself were the only portion of our family assembled at dinner this day— It was yesterday twenty-two years since we last kept thanksgiving in this house— Nor have I excepting the last year been within the State on a Thanksgiving day since— This was also the birth-day of my Son John’s eldest daughter Louisa, who is two years old, and whom we duly remembered— After dinner I walked with Charles to the Mount Wollaston farm, and inspected the new planted Orchard. Alpheus Spear was there, and I remarked that the violent gales and heavy rains since the Trees were planted had already started many of them from the perpendicular line. Returning home we called at my brother’s, and I spent the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s; with a numerous party—

3. IV:30. Friday— Charles and his wife returned this morning to Boston— My wife went with them, intending to proceed this afternoon, or to-morrow, on her journey to Washington— She goes with our Carriage and one pair of horses; driven by John Kirke, and accompanied by Mrs Pitts. She proposes going by Land to New Haven, and there take a day Steam boat to New-York— As she will probably not reach New Haven before this day week, my project is after finishing my business at the Probate Court in Dedham next Tuesday, to go from thence into Boston; remain there the next day— Take the Stage on Thursday, and overtake my wife the next Evening at New-Haven— My brother’s daughters Abigail and Elizabeth were here when my wife went away, and she engaged Abigail to come and stay with me till my departure— I was occupied the greater part of the day in preparing my papers for the Probate Court— My brother dined with me— Josiah Adams was here for about an hour before dinner, and his brother Ebenezer, as long in the afternoon— Josiah agreed that they would take on lease next Summer my Druid Lots, bordering upon their Lands; and we spoke of the draining of the brook; but without coming to any definitive arrangement concerning it— These two brothers reside in two separate small houses, on the very spot where their and my Great-grandfather Joseph Adams junr. lived— His eldest Son Joseph was the Minister at Newington. His second Son, John was my Grandfather; who settled about a mile distant, at the foot of Penn’s Hill— His third Son Ebenezer inherited this paternal Estate, and lived and died on the place; leaving it to his Son Ebenezer, who was near about the age of my father, and was the father of these two brothers. They remain, in precisely the same station of life as was held by their and my common ancestor, of whom I consider them as exact representatives. They are good farmers, and have been victuallers. Josiah is a Deacon of the Church, and their wives are both Sisters of Mr Whitney the Minister of the Parish— It is a subject of instructive reflection, to compare the condition of those branches
of the family of Joseph Adams, who have received a College Education, with that of those, which have not had that Advantage. The Education places them in another sphere of life—but who infers from thence that they are happier shocks all common sense.

4. V. Saturday. I wrote to Mr Benjamin Vaughan of Hallowell, and enclosed the part of his manuscripts which I have found here to Mr Gideon Snow at Boston as he had desired— Received a Note from my Son Charles, mentioning that his mother had proceeded at 3. yesterday afternoon upon her Journey to New-Haven, and making enquiry for some articles she had left behind— I paid my last visit for the Season to my Nursery, and Garden. S. Farrar dug up Stones almost by the Ton from the last row that I had opened of the stony-barren— After digging about five feet deep, and finding stones still below, I had not time for continuing the search and had the vacant space filled with pomace and pignuts; despairing of any useful future production upon that spot. Took up one young Apple tree, which I set out in the garden. Set out one Baldwin Apple-tree in the midst of the Stony-barren. Ten in the Garden. Also two white mulberry-trees and six Slips— I sent one of the Quart Tumblers containing the white Oak Acorns to Price Greenleaf, who promised to take care of it— The other I leave with Mrs Kirk who is to remain here this winter. Also the green box in which the unknown flower has come up; and the other boxes and flower-pots in which I have planted seeds— Dined at my brother’s— Mr Marston, P. Whitney, and Mr Potter, who is officiating as Minister of the Episcopal Church were there— Mr George Davis a young Student at the theological school at Cambridge came in the afternoon. I returned home at Sunset, and my niece, Abigail S. Adams with her Cousin Caroline Harrod, daughter of Mr Joseph Harrod of Portland came in the Evening to stay with me till my departure— This young Lady is engaged to be married to a Son of the late B. Bartlett of Haverhill: but he is in Peru and there is a perplexing question, whether he shall come for her, or she shall go to him, not yet definitively settled.
5. IV:30. Sunday.— Sun rose 7:28. behind the third house.

Heard Mr Whitney from Colossians 3.2. [“]Set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth— 3. For ye are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God. 4. When Christ, who is our life, shall appear, then shall ye also appear with him in glory.” After the Sermon upon which he administered the communion. His afternoon discourse was from 1. Corinthians 13.4. [“]Charity suffereth long and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up. 5. Doth not behave itself unseemly; seeketh not her own; is not easily provoked; thinketh no evil.” After Meeting I asked Deacon Spear to call on me to-morrow morning, and I told Mr Noah Curtis that I should be glad to have the Parish Treasurers Note of 1400 dollars to the Executors of my father’s Will paid, as soon as convenient— He said he could have paid it last week; but was not now in funds. I said it would suit me any time in the course of the Winter. My damsel Visitors left me this morning, and Miss Harrod did not come back till the Evening. Abby came with her brother Isaac Hull, and dined with me. My boy John Phillips left me— His father and mother came for him— We had
proposed that he should remain here with Mrs Kirk, and go to school until our return in the Spring: his mother, a worthy laborious Irish woman, told me she approved highly of this plan, but that the boy himself disinclined to stay after the Quality were gone— Miss Harrod came back this Evening; and my brother with his daughter Elizabeth, Mr Beale, Mr Gourgas, Daniel and Price, Greenleaf and Edward Miller successively called in friendly neighbourhood— I finished reading this morning the third Volume of the English Translation of Calmet’s Dictionary— Consisting of fragments illustrative of the Scriptures. It has greatly disappointed me, and I consider the time which I have devoted to it as almost entirely wasted— It is a costly work, loaded with a multitude of copper Plate engravings, of very little use for the illustration of the Scriptures— Its principal pretension is to collect testimony from books of Travels in the East, to explain particular passages of the Old Testament— There is a very long and very superfluous new Translation of Solomon’s Song, with a commentary to prove that it was a dramatic epithalamium, divided into six Sections of morning and Evening. There had been quite enough mystification of Solomon’s Song before— The attempt to prove that Jonah’s whale, or great fish was a ship is more reasonable, and not without merit. There is nothing better in the Book— The Dissertations upon Dagon and Derketos are curious, and led me to wish I could consult Selden’s book upon the Syrian Mythology— The Geography of Palestine at the several periods from Abraham’s emigration out of Mesopotamia to the days of the Apostles and the Voyages of St. Paul, have interest, but all that can be known upon this subject may be learnt by comparison of the maps in half an hour— The miraculous character of the Jewish history is made the more astonishing by taking from the map an accurate inspection of the diminutive space within which they were forty years wandering between Rameses and the river Jordan, before their establishment in the land of promise—but every spot of earth, and every drop of water from Dan to Beersheba, is spiritualized by the wonders of the old Testament and the new— It is fairy Land— The region of enchantment— The Laws of Nature are now the same there as in other parts of the globe; but who can ascend Horeb or Sinai, and believe that he is treading upon common dust—who can enter a boat upon the Sea of Gennesareth and think that he floats upon a common wave— Abbana and Pharpar are Rivers of Damascus, and may be such as they were in the days of Naaman, but what is that Jordan, by washing in the waters of which the Leper was cleansed? I dare not pursue this subject—but I have derived as yet little instruction or edification from the English Editor of Calmet.
6. IV. Monday.

I was occupied the whole of this day, in preparing for my Journey, and in drawing up the papers for the Settlement of the Executor’s Account, at the Probate Court in Dedham to-morrow; in copying which I was assisted by my young female visitors. Deacon Spear called this morning, and signed a Certificate of the Sale of the two remaining woodlots of my father’s Estate, and also a receipt for the dividends on the Potowmac bridge stock, received for him as Administrator of Ruth Cleverly, by my Son John at Washington— Josiah Adams was also here and I settled his Account— Yesterday and the day before had been two of the finest days of the year, and I was rejoicing at the good Fortune with which my wife was proceeding upon her journey. Mr Brigham who returned on Friday Evening from a Journey to the western part of the State, had met her that afternoon at Watertown, intending to lodge that Night at Waltham—but he gives a formidable account of the roads, and says that 20 miles west of Worcester there was last week a foot deep of Snow— This morning was Cloudy, and about ten
it began to rain with a Northeastern gale which soon compelled me to close the blinds of my chamber’s Eastern window— As the storm increased, the atmosphere became colder and as we sat at dinner my niece remarked that it was turning to Snow. From that time till my senses were steeped in forgetfulness near midnight raged one of the fiercest Snow-storms of Mid winter— I despaired of being able to go to Dedham with a horse and Chaise to-morrow morning, and sent to Gillet to engage a seat in the Stage to Boston— I read a part of William Tudor’s Manuscripts; but they are so voluminous that I shall be obliged to leave them here, and consequently to postpone writing the biographical notice of him, for the North-American Review.
7. V. Tuesday— Dedham— Probate Court— Boston.

Awaking at about four this morning I heard the Gale still howling, and supposed that the Snow-storm continued— On rising and looking out of the Window, I saw the Moon breaking through the clouds and perceived that the Snow had ceased and that the Gale was blowing from the North-west— The Stage came and took Mrs Holley, our Cook into Boston, and I sent S. Farrar to Gillet’s for a horse, to take me in my own Chaise to Dedham and Boston— Immediately after breakfast, my brother’s Son Joseph H. came for the two young Ladies, and they returned home— Between 9 and 10. I left my house in the Chaise with S. Farrar— I called at Dr Holbrook’s in Milton, to ask him for his bill; and as he had it not ready engaged him to send it, when made out to my Son Charles. It was not without difficulty that we reached Dedham just before noon; the Snow having in several places drifted deeply across the road; and at one of them the Chaise was stall’d and in imminent danger of being overset. By taking the horse out, and with the assistance of other way-farers who successively came up we got through. At the Probate Court in Dedham, I found President Quincy, who said he had been waiting for me an hour. We settled the fifth and sixth Accounts of the Executors of my father; not without some difficulties made by the Judge, Sherman Leland, who now proposed to postpone again, the acceptance of the accounts to give notice to all concerned before he should pass them; though at the Court in Quincy last Month he had told me he should dispense with this as an unnecessary formality. I reminded him of that circumstance, and of his reference then to a recent decision of the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth that a decree of a judge of a Probate Court was not necessarily final, for the passage of an Executor’s Account; but might be years afterwards revised by the Supreme Court— I also informed him that the accounts were prepared in precise conformity with his directions— That I proposed making the second distribution of the proceeds of the Estate, on the first of January next to the devisees. And as I was now going immediately to Washington to pass the Winter, I should not for several Months have it in my power to attend the Probate Court again— The judge at first seemed unwilling to acknowledge my statement of what he had said to me at the last Court in Quincy, but Mr Haven the Register remembered it, and said he had understood him as I did— The judge said that if he should pass the accounts without an order of notice they would have no validity—that is that they might be revised many years hereafter by the Supreme Court— I told him I was perfectly willing that they should
remain subject to the revisal of the Supreme Court to the end of time, if any of the parties interested should so desire. He finally examined the vouchers and passed the Accounts, administering the Oaths to Mr Quincy and me— After we came out Mr Quincy explained the cause of the Judge’s mutability since the November Court. He said there was another Executor in Court with whom the Judge had been half an hour contesting the same point before I came in— The judge having exacted the giving of notice from him, had concluded that he could not in presence of the same person, dispense with it from us; as he certainly would not, but for Mr Haven’s remembrance— Mr Quincy went with me to Bride’s tavern, and thence to the Office of the Register of Deeds, and the Office of the Clerk of the Courts— We executed the Deed to me of the two remaining Woodlots of my father’s Estate; acknowledged it before Judge Jairus Ware, who with Mr James Richardson witnessed it; and I left it to be recorded. I executed also a bond to the Executors, obligating myself to pay the portion of the second distribution to the three children of my brothers, yet minors, and that part of the bequest to my brother conformably to the Will— I signed also an engagement to pay the second distribution of 125 dollars to each of the devisees, taking the endorsement to me of the Quincy Parish Treasurer’s Note for 1400 dollars; and a check, transferring to me the balance credited to the Executors, in the U.S. Branch Bank Boston; after first giving a check to Mr Quincy for half the allowance of compensation to the Executors— He said he had never intended to make his agency in this affair a concern of money; but he would take the check, and would readily contribute to the expence of erecting the School-house, proposed by my father— After finishing these papers I dined at Bride’s and immediately after dinner came into Boston. Alighted at my Son Charles’s House, and sent S. Farrar with the horse and Chaise back to Quincy. The road from Dedham to Boston was not quite so much obstructed with Snow as that from Quincy to Dedham; but the North-west gale blew, and the snow was drifting the whole day. I found at his house, Letters from his mother to him, written Friday Evening at Waltham and Saturday Evening at Worcester; and one to me, of Sunday Evening at Sturbridge— I had intended to remain to-morrow at Boston; but apprehensive of the obstructions which this fall of Snow may have occasioned on the road, and finding that I could finish all the business necessary at this time, this Evening, I sent and engaged a Seat in the Stage to go at nine to-morrow Morning for Hartford. I was engaged part of the Evening with Charles in arrangements of business, and in conversation with Mr John B. Davis, who called in, for the remainder.
8. V. Wednesday.— Stage, on the way from Boston to Hartford.

I had finished reading the second Book of Kings yesterday; and this morning in Charles’s Study read three Chapters of the first Book of Chronicles—but I could not write— I left with Charles Letters to Mr De Wint, Mr A. B. Johnson, and Mrs Susan B. Clark, to be signed by Mr Quincy and forwarded, my bank Books to be balanced; and left with Charles the necessary directions for the distributions to the devisees— At 9. the Stage called for me, and took the way to Hartford— The Passengers were a Revd. Mr Searle, Mrs Hale his Sister, with two infant daughters of four and two years of age, a Frenchman named Governo, one passenger who left us at Brighton, and one at Northbridge— The Carriage went heavily, and the wheels were hardly drawn through the drifts of Snow; at Newton just before Noon we were fairly stalled. Two Stages, in Sleighs from the westward soon came up, and for one of them we exchanged our Carriage. At Needham about one we took fresh horses, and were warned that the Stage from Hartford which should have reached there yesterday Noon had not yet arrived; and that another after attempting to labour through the Snow drifts with six Oxen, had failed, and returned back to Sutton— We proceeded through Framingham, Upton, and some other town to Hopkinton; where they gave us again a Carriage upon wheels, assuring us it would be impracticable to travel in a Sleigh; three fourths of the ground being bare, and Snow drifts six feet deep across the road for the other fourth. We should have dined at Hopkinton at one, but it
was 3 before we reached there, and no symptoms of dinner were to be seen— We came on, fasting through Northbridge to Sutton, where about nine in the Evening we obtained a very comfortable Supper— We had been obliged to alight several times as well from the Sleigh, as from the Coach— Often to turn out from the road into deep furrowed Corn field’s—to break up Rail-fences, break down Stone Walls, and drive over rock, and through ditches. My companion Mr Searle, at the Supper table said a blessing for our escape from the dangers we had past, and prayed to avert those yet before us: after supper we started afresh from Sutton, about eleven O’Clock took in a young woman roused from bed to take the Stage, and just about Midnight were stalled again— Here we remained fast about an hour; till we had sent back for additional help— At length by shovelling away the Snow, applying Shoulders to the wheels, and the Scourge to the horses the Carriage lightened of all the male passengers got a new start and

9. Thursday—at half past one in the morning we arrived at Woodstock— This was the place, which in the regular course of the stage we should have reached at 7. O’Clock last Evening, and where we should have lodged till four this morning— We thought it best however not to stop for the short time left, and proceeded as soon as our driver would go 1/2 past two. leaving our transient passenger behind— They gave us here again a Sleigh which was dragged chiefly over bare ground, through Thompson to Ashford—where at 6 in the Morning we found a breakfast in waiting for us— The house is kept by a person named Clarke, and a family of three generations appeared to be in attendance— An old man and woman each little short of 70. two women in middle age, apparently married, and a youth and maiden under twenty, all occupied with the business of the house— Our next Stage was Vernon after passing through Tolland a handsome Village and the first Town in Connecticut beyond the Massachusetts border. At Vernon a Coach with wheels was again given us, and we came through Mansfield and East Hartford over the Bridge to Hartford— We landed from the Stage, all safe and unhurt, about 1/2 past one at the Exchange Coffee-house. My wife not being there, nor at the Hartford Hotel, where I enquired after her, I found her, with Mrs Pitts and John Kirk at the United States Hotel— She came from Sturbridge to Tolland, in the Snow-Storm on Monday— Remained at Tolland on Tuesday; and yesterday travelling again with infinite difficulty through the Snow arrived here last Evening. One of the horses being ill, they could not proceed this day to New-Haven. There was no Steam-boat from hence to New-York this day; but the Victory is to go at 1. P.M. to-morrow. Mr. Governo called upon me to offer his excuses for not knowing who I was till we arrived here, and to ask some questions as to his means of proceeding to New-York— He is a young French-man, an Officer, he says in the service of the Emperor of Brazil— Arrived last week at Boston, from Surinam, and seeking a passage now to Rio De Janeiro. He speaks not a word of our language, and complains that this inability is made a subject of rudeness and ridicule, and not of polite and obliging helpfulness as it would be to a stranger in France. He sat dull and silent yesterday morning in a corner of the Stage, with a pint bottle of cordial, which he applied occasionally to his lips— Mr Searle I suppose a Temperance Society man, at last said to him with a good-humoured smile—“not good”— He then
gave us to understand that he could not speak our language and I accosted him in French. He was delighted to find some one with whom he could talk, and was afterwards full of conversation— He made no further use of his bottle, and when I asked him this morning what had become of it, he said he had thrown it away— Pride, good-nature and a quick sense of honour were discernible in his character. He told me that none of the Frenchmen whom he had seen at Boston were persons of distinction, or fit company for him— At Vernon, in the bar-room of the house where our horses were changed there were two men talking in French, upon France, Louis Philippe and La Fayette— One of them was evidently an American, and spoke with an English accent.— The other seemed to me a German; but my fellow-traveller took him for a Frenchman, and I supposed would have spoken to him— But he did not, and assigned to me as his reason for silence, that he had no doubt the man was quelque Cordonnier— We had rain all last Night and part of this Morning while on the road.— It recommenced this afternoon and continued all the Evening: not withstanding which we had a number of Visitors— Among whom were Judge Russ, and his two daughters—Mr Wadsworth; Mrs Law—Charles Babcock, Editor of the Hartford Mercury, and his brother, who importuned me much to call upon his mother—Mr Le Clerc of the Asylum for the Deaf and Dumb called in the Evening and I promised to visit that Establishment to-morrow.
10. VII. Friday.— Steam-Boat Victory from Hartford to Saybrook.

Mr Burgess one of our last Evening Visitors, brought me this Morning the National Intelligencer of last Tuesday, and the Extra Sheet containing the Message of the President at the opening of the second Session of the 21st. Congress. We had several other visitors this morning, and among them Mr Charles Sigourney. With Mrs. Adams I visited the Asylum of the Deaf and Dumb, and saw an exhibition of three of the Classes there—the first of which were all natives of Massachusetts—the Legislature of that State having made a liberal provision for their support. Mr Le Clerc himself one of the earliest pupils of the Institution, was himself instructing them— Mr Weld formerly the teacher of the School at Philadelphia, and whom we have since seen at Washington is now here— We also saw in a separate Apartment, a young woman named Julia Brace—deaf, dumb and blind—sitting alone beside a table and knitting— Mr Weld approached and took her hand; but she cast off his with apparent displeasure— He attempted to take from her lap a handkerchief which she had been hemming; but she resisted and struggled to retain it— She took Mrs Adams’s hand with readiness; felt inquisitively along the fringe of her veil, and silk knots of her Cloak, and pressed separately the end of each finger of her hand— The matron of the Institution coming in she readily received her hand—yielded at once the handkerchief which she had denied to Mr Weld, and threaded a needle which the Matron put into her hands to exhibit an example of what she could do— We necessarily shortened our visit and returned to the Hotel, where Mr Gallaudet called upon me— He is to be considered as the first, and principal founder of this Institution— He told me there were now sixteen of the same kind in the United States— We had given up all idea of going by Land to New-Haven—the roads being almost impracticable; and at Noon we embarked in the Steam-boat Victory, Captain Sherman; who was however not on board— A Mr Richards one of the proprietors acted as Captain: also a Mr Wurgman— I made my excuses to Mr Babcock, for not visiting his mother and Sister owing to the shortness of the Time. He followed us on board the boat, and remained with me to the last Moment. The Steam-boat M’Donogh, which arrived only this Morning
from New-York, departed again an hour before the Victory. All my fellow passengers in the Stage from Boston were in the M’Donogh— There is competition, professional and political between these Boats— The proprietors of the Victory call her the People’s boat, and others call her the Jackson boat— We were urged to take passage in the M’Donogh, but had engaged our passage in the other before she arrived— The Victory is the boat of greatest speed, and in descending the river overtook the M’Donogh just as she reached Saybrook, at the dusk of Evening— Both boats were moored here for the Night, unwilling to encounter the Gale, and swell, heaving the Waters of the Sound— We were visited by several Passengers of the Fanny, a Steam-boat from Norwich and New-London which came out on Wednesday but was obliged to put in here yesterday and has remained here all this day. Mr Richards talks of going out at Midnight if the gale abates— One reason which he assigns for not going out this evening is that it is low-tide—with not more than 4 1/2 feet Water on the bar at the mouth of the river, while the boat draws 7 feet— The descent of the Connecticut River is pleasant in the mild Seasons and with fair weather—but this day was raw and gusty, and the banks of the River were powdered and the distant hills bleached with Snow—constantly diminishing however, as we came Southward, till at the Mouth of the river scarcely any Snow is to be seen— From Boston to Hartford the Storm was about of the same continuance, at the same time and fell and drifted in the same manner— I am told however that 20 miles west of Hartford there was scarcely any fall of Snow— All Rain.
11. VII. Saturday— Steam-boat Victory, from Saybrook to New-York.

We came out from Saybrook, just at Sunrise, with a brisk, cold, Northwest wind, almost a gale, and a heavy swell, which made the Ladies, and several of the male passengers sick— There was a heavy foaming surf upon the bar, but the boat passed over it without striking. The whole day was blustering, and banished us mostly from the decks into the Cabins— I had a new set of fellow passengers, all total Strangers to me. I had no book and was reduced to the resources of Conversation in which I freely (too freely) indulged, upon various topics, and with many of the passengers. They were of very diverse characters, foreign and domestic, some educated, and highly polished, others rude and untutored, coarse and vulgar. I was treated with great respect by many of them, and not disrespectfully by any one. I discovered the names only of two or three— One a Mr Thompson of New-York, a merchant of grave and gentle deportment— A young man named Hollister who spoke much of his claim to a patent right, contested and which he could not substantiate for a lack of means to feed a Law-suit. With another young man, perhaps named Goodwin, I had talk upon Electricity, Magnetism, Galvanism, Light, the figure of the globe, matter, Spirit, and atheistic philosophy. With others I talked Politics, of the recent Revolution in France, and the celebration of it at New-York, Prospects of War in Europe, and all the topics of the President’s Message. I told of my first voyage to France, and others of my adventures— Garrulous Old Age— The M’Donogh left Saybrook half an hour before us: but the Victory soon came up with her, and ran her out of sight during the day. The Fanny followed us out of Connecticut River; but we soon lost Sight of her and it was supposed she found the Swell too heavy, and returned or went
in to New-Haven— We buffeted the waves the whole day, entered the East-river at Sands’s point at the dusk of Evening, and passing Hellgate in the dark, landed between nine and ten at New-York. We took lodgings at the City Hotel, kept by Chester Jennings. Mrs Adams who always suffers much by Steamboat travelling was now weakened by Sea-Sickness and quite unwell— Our horses were landed, the Carriage remaining on board the Boat, till Morning— Mr Richards gave me a long account of the competition of his boat with the owners of the Oliver Ellsworth and the M’Donogh, and as he told the Tale, put them much in the wrong—
12. VII. Sunday— Remaining at New-York.

Mr James Brown, our late Minister to France, was lodging here, and spent half an hour with us while we were at breakfast— He was then summoned to embark, having taken passage in a vessel for New-Orleans— Since we saw him last May in Philadelphia, he has lost his wife, who after a lingering and threatening illness died almost instantaneously about three Months since. He is himself very unwell, and looks like a man bowed down to the Earth— He goes to New-Orleans to meet Mr Clay— He spoke of the Message; and of an Article of severe comment upon it in Walsh’s National Gazette— Dr Hosack and Joseph Blunt called on me as the Bells were ringing for Church, and I went and heard Mr Wainwright read the Episcopal Morning service for the third Sunday in Advent. I never before heard the prayer-book read better if so well— The Sermon was from Matthew 11.7. “And as they departed, Jesus began to say unto the Multitudes concerning John, what went ye out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken with the wind? 8. But what went ye out for to see? A man clothed in soft raiment? Behold, they that wear soft clothing are in king’s houses. 9. But what went ye out for to see? A prophet? yea, I say unto and more than a prophet. 10. For this is he of whom it is written— Behold I send my Messenger before thy face, which shall prepare thy way before thee— 11. Verily I say unto you, Among them that are born of women, there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist: notwithstanding he that is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he. 12. And from the days of John the Baptist, until now, the kingdom of heaven, suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force— 13. For all the prophets and the Law prophesied until John 14. And if ye will receive it, this is Elias, which was for to come. 15. He that hath Ears to hear, let him hear.” This text was from the gospel of the day—and the discourse was upon the Office, Character and influence of John the Baptist— It was in handsome Style, ingenious and eloquent; but that text and the Character of John the Baptist were not to be duly expounded in the compass of a Sermon of half an hour— After Church we received visits from Mr and then Miss Davis—Sidney Brooks—Miss Parker one of our passengers in the Steam boat yesterday—with a Mr and Mrs Waldron; and Mr W. B. Lawrence. Joseph Blunt dined with us. After dinner I visited Mr Monroe at his Son in Law’s Samuel L Gouverneur’s. Mrs Hay was also there— Gouverneur is going to-morrow for Washington— Mr Monroe’s health is infirm and his appearance feeble and emaciated— Mrs Monroe and Judge Hay died about 3 months since within a week of each other. Mr Monroe told me that Henry Lee had written to him concerning certain correspondence which had passed between General Jackson and Mr Monroe at two periods— The defence of New-Orleans, and the taking of St Marks and
Pensacola. Lee contending that Jackson was authorised to make those captures. He spoke also of his correspondence with H. L. White on his Speech at dinner 8. Jany. 1829. said Forsyth had reported to Jackson Calhoun’s proposal to bring Jackson to trial for breach of Orders in taking St. Marks and Pensacola; and mentioned a Letter said by Crawford to have been referred to by Calhoun, and produced by Mr Monroe, at the Cabinet Meetings on the Seminole War— Mr Monroe said Crawford and Calhoun had both written to him concerning that Letter from Jackson, in which he had written that he would take the Spanish Forts in Florida, if without writing at all Mr Monroe would barely say to John Rhea that he might go on. Mr Monroe said that he had never read this Letter from Jackson till some Months after the Cabinet Meetings— That he received it when ill of a fever— That he had answered Crawford’s to him, concerning it, by referring him to the members of the Administration who were present at the Meetings—Calhoun— Wirt and myself— I told him that Crawford had written to me concerning it— The purport of my answer; and that I had received from him no reply. He spoke also of the Correspondence between General Jackson, and Mr Southard, respecting some remarks made by Mr Southard at a dinner Table in Fredericksburg, reported and misrepresented by a Tale-bearer. Mr Monroe said Jackson had treated him very ill in that Correspondence. Gouverneur thought otherwise, that Jackson had cautiously avoided all disrespectful notice of Mr Monroe; but had treated Southard himself with brutality. Mr Monroe said he would shew me the correspondence relating to the transactions in the Seminole War— I called at Liberty Street N. 101. and was answered by a female voice from within the house, who called to enquire who was there without opening the door— I enquired for Mr and Mrs De Wint, and was told that they had returned to Fishkill Landing. Mr George Sullivan with Son, paid us a visit this Evening.
13. V. Monday—

My wife went with John Kirk and Mrs Pitts in the Steam-boat New-York, of the Union Line, at Noon, for Brunswick, intending to proceed this Evening, with her Carriage and Horses to Kingston. There to sleep and go on to morrow morning to Trenton, where I am to overtake her by the Morning Union-Line— I accompanied her to the boat, and saw it cast off 5 minutes after Noon— Mr Gouverneur went in the boat. Soon after my return to the City Hotel, David Williams, the only surviving captor of Major André, with one of the Aldermen, and another young man, came to visit me. He had the silver medal given him by Congress, hung over his neck, by a three coloured silk ribband— He said he was 77 years of age; and he related to me all the Circumstances of the taking of André— He was anxious to obtain an increase of his pension of 200 dollars a year—and was warmly seconded by the Alderman, who said the pension had been sufficient for his comfortable maintenance, while he was young, and able to work upon his farm— That was now in the possession of his Son, a respectable man who worked upon it himself. But the days of labour of the old man were now past, and some addition to his pittance of pension was necessary to make the remnant of his life easy. I advised that he should petition Congress, and get the member of the House from his district to present and support his petition; which I hoped and believed would be successful. He expressed deep mortification that the integrity of the captors of André should have been disputed— I observed that it never had been in Congress but once and that their honour had then been signally vindicated. He solemnly asseverated, that he and his partners hesitated not a single instant in rejecting
André’s climax of Offers, from ten to ten thousand guineas, and dry goods to any amount they would ask— He spoke in terms of high veneration of my father, who he said had done more for the Revolution than he had, though in a different way— Mr Pitcairn called and was with me while Williams told his Story. Leslie Combs of Kentucky, a Mr Carter and G. M. Blunt visited me. Genl. Van Rensselaer the Patroon, and Mr Charles King left Cards— Joseph Blunt dined with me, and agreed if he could so arrange his business to go on with me to Philadelphia to-morrow. After dinner I visited Daniel M’Cormick, 86 years of age— Saw there Mr Pitcairn, Mr Brodie, and Pitcairn’s Son in Law, a German— On returning to the City Hotel, about 8 in the Evening, I found there cards of visit from Mr and Mrs James A. Hamilton; to Mrs Adams and myself; and Notes of Invitation, from Mrs Hamilton to us both, to a party at their house this Evening. As Mrs Adams had left the City I thought it best to go and make her apology myself— I went about nine, and was the first person there— The company soon began to come— It was a Ball, and I found myself out of my Element— Most of the company were of the second generation after me—but Mr Hamilton’s mother was there— His daughter, about seventeen was one of the belles—with a bell hoop— He introduced his Son to me, a boy of 12 or 13— Mr and Mrs Davis, Mr James King; Mr Dominic Lynch, and Edward Coles were of my acquaintance— As the company thickened I retired about ten O’Clock to my Lodgings— Mrs Hamilton before her Marriage was a school-mate and companion of my niece Mrs De Wint— There was a very numerous popular Meeting this Evening, which nominated Henry Clay as a Candidate for Election to the Presidency of the United States, and passed sundry spirited Resolutions.
14. VI. Tuesday— From New-York to Philadelphia.— U.S. Hotel— Renshaw’s.

At 7 this Morning I left the City Hotel at New-York, and embarked in the Steam-boat Swan, of the Union Line. Left the wharf 5 minutes after 7—13 minutes to the first Island; 40 minutes to the Staten Island Point. 1 hour 10 minutes to Elizabeth Town point. 2 hours 15 minutes to the Raritan House at Perth-Amboy—4 hours to the Landing at New Brunswick. Blunt was not with us. We landed at 11. and proceeded in the Stage to Trenton, where at 3. in the afternoon, we embarked in the Steamboat Trenton— My wife, with her Servants, Carriage and Horses was already there— They came on last Evening as far as Kingston, where they lodged; of which the master of the House, at Mrs Adams’s request gave me notice when the stage stopped there, as we came through. It rained the whole day, and as Evening came on the darkness was so great, that neither shore of the river could be seen from the boat, and there was prospect that we should be compelled to anchor for the Night in the River. We did however reach Philadelphia between 8 and 9 in the Evening— Went to Head’s at the Mansion House, but they were full, and could not receive us. We obtained admission and lodgings at the United States Hotel—Renshaw’s— In the Boat from New-York and Stage from Brunswick there was not an individual with whom I had any previous acquaintance; but there were several who knew me— At the Raritan house, Major Lamb came on board and accompanied us to New-Brunswick—and at Trenton a Mr Taylor who resides near the Jersey line, in Pennsylvania, and whom I had met in the boat when I was going last Winter to Washington; and again, last June when I was returning to Quincy, joined us— Mr Taylor was under great excitement at the recent Message of the President of the United States, to Congress; and particularly at the renewed attack upon the Bank of the United States— One of the Passengers
in the boat from New-York to New-Brunswick mentioned that some disclosures had been made by Joseph J. Knapp, under Sentence of Death at Salem for the murder of Joseph White, which deeply implicated his niece and housekeeper Mrs Beckford, as privy to the whole conspiracy. These disclosures were made last week, by or in consequence of a Letter from Knap to the Governor, with the view of obtaining a Pardon— Of the perpetrators of this murder, one, Richard Crowninshield, strangled himself in prison— One, Franklin Knapp has been hung—his brother is under Sentence of death— George Crowninshield has been acquitted upon two trials—one Capital, for Murder, and the other, for conspiracy with intent to murder— The passenger said that the excitement last week at Salem was very great.
15. V. Wednesday— Philadelphia—

Copious rain all Night and early this Morning. After Breakfast Mr Nicklin called—and informed me that Mr Southard was at a Hotel in 3d. Street, where I immediately accompanied Mr Nicklin, and found him— He is only recovering from a violent bilious fever which confined him upwards of three Months— He was going to Gloucester County upon business as Attorney General, but had been advised by his friends and physicians not to proceed in this weather. His nephew and another young man were with him, but retired, as did Mr Nicklin— I had an hour of Conversation with him, in which with reference to this Correspondence of Crawford and Calhoun with Mr Monroe, concerning the Cabinet Meetings on the Transactions of the Seminole War, I mentioned the Scene at the last Cabinet Meeting of Mr. Monroe’s Administration which Crawford attended—when I was commenting severely upon Porter’s exploit at Porto-Rico, Crawford, though concurring in the Opinion that Porter’s conduct had been utterly lawless, broke out, in a burst of fury—[“]Jackson’s conduct in Florida was ten times worse.” Southard said he remembered it perfectly— After leaving Mr Southard, I called at the Bank of the United States— Mr John Connell came in while I was there; and Mr Gratz—a Relation of Mr Clay’s from Kentucky. Mr. Biddle invited me to dine with him and I accepted. Mrs Adams sent for Miss Mease, who came and dined with her— We sent John Kirke by the Boat to Newcastle, with the Horses and Carriage to meet us to-morrow, at Black Creek— Several Visitors called— Among whom was Coll. Watmough, who is a member elect of the next Congress. A Mr Christopher Blackburne, delivered a Letter of introduction from William Frend from whom I received many civilities when I was last in England— He now resides at Stoke-Newington, where his Letter is dated 26. August last. At Mr Biddle’s I met judge Hopkinson, R. Walsh, and R. Peters— Much Conversation, on the President’s Message, and the new attack on the Bank of the United States: on the Prospects of Election, of a Senator of the United States at Harrisburg in the place of William Marks; and on a complaint from Charleston S.C. against the President of the U.S. Branch Bank there, for taking an anxious interest in the City Elections to the State Legislature. There was discussion also upon the propriety of my taking a Seat in the House of Representatives
of the Unites States: Hopkinson and Walsh disapproving—Biddle and Peters approving. John Sergeant who came in after dinner, being with some reserve also in the negative— On returning to my lodgings I found Mr and Mrs Sergeant there; calling on Mrs Adams.— Wallenstein had been there before dinner, and he shewed me a Letter from Count Capo d’Istrias to him— Mr Southard had also called with his daughter Virginia, grown to Woman’s Estate, since we had seen her.
16. V. Thursday.

We left Philadelphia, at 7 this morning in the Steam-boat William Penn, Captainand at 11. landed at what they call the Delaware City where we passed into the Canal Boat— It was near 2. P.M. when we reached the head of Black Creek, where we found John Kirk with the Horses and Carriage already on board the Steam-boat Carroll of Carrollton—Captain Chaytor— We arrived at Baltimore about 7. in the Evening, and took lodgings at Barnum’s Hotel— The morning was a Clear, Cold, Northwester; but it soon clouded up, and the day was chilly and blustering, and confined us almost entirely to the Cabins of the Boats— Among the Passengers was a young Mr Hone with whom I travelled last Winter from New-York to Philadelphia— He had now with him his wife and a pretty daughter nine or ten years of age— Mr and Mrs Hone were at Mr James A. Hamilton’s Ball on Monday Night; and remained there they told me till 3. the next Morning. He introduced to me Charles Clinton, husband of his wife’s Sister and eldest Son of the late Governor De Witt Clinton. There was also a Mr Lloyd of Maryland, who announced himself as a Son of a sometime General Lloyd who fought a duel with Robert Wright. Nephew of a former and cousin of the late Governor Lloyd a member now or late of the Senate of Maryland— He had his wife with him; a beautiful young woman said to be a daughter of my Old Schoolmate Benjamin Franklin Bache. Mr Lloyd specially signalized himself by boisterous drunkenness, interrupted only by an interval of Sleep on a bench, while all the rest of the company were dining: and by noisy and noxious Maledictions upon Benjamin Chew junr. whom he said he would kill, if it were not wasting powder and ball upon such a rascal: for he could hit a dollar at ten yards distance. A more amusing fellow traveller was an old slight acquaintance who introduced himself by the name of Matthew L. Davis of New-York—a man heretofore distinguished as a political partizan of great activity, but of whom I had scarcely heard for several years— He had been formerly an ardent friend of Aaron Burr; and after his downfall, had slided into obscurity. But he now gave himself out as devoted to Mr Clay, and strongly intimated that his influence had decided the nomination at the Meeting in New-York last Monday Night— He communicated to me as a great secret that there was in the New Treaty with Turkey a Secret Article by which the Turkish Government were authorized to build Ships of War, and to procure Warlike Stores, in the Ports of the United States. He told me that he had been in intimate Correspondence with W. H. Crawford; and spoke of him as a person for whom he now entertained great regard. He spoke much of the publication of Jefferson’s Correspondence, every line of which he had read over twice; and he intimated that it gave him a very indifferent opinion of Jefferson himself. He said that he had caused a suit at Law, between two of his Clerks to be commenced, upon a wager, for the sake of taking depositions, and perpetuating the testimony relating to the intrigues in the House of Representatives at the Election of 1801. There were
depositions also taken in a suit commenced by Aaron Burr against James Cheetham but never tried— Davis said there had been very recently a further correspondence upon the Subject, in which General Samuel Smith had written a somewhat equivocal and prevaricating Letter— We found E. J. Coale at Barnum’s in Baltimore. He had dined with my Son John at Washington last Sunday.
17. V. Friday— From Baltimore to Washington— Rail-road ride.

Mr Coale had engaged for me a passage in the Stage for Washington—to leave Baltimore at ten this Morning: but Mr Philip K. Thomas President of the Rail-road Company; and Mrone of the Directors came just at our breakfast time, and so warmly urged an excursion upon the Rail-road both to Mrs Adams and myself that we could not refuse. At ten this morning therefore we went to the depot in a Carriage belonging to the Company, Mr Thomas, Mr Patterson, and several other directors of the Company were with us. And Sir William Campbell Chief Justice of Canada, who is travelling Southward for his health. We were a few minutes belated in arriving at the depot, after the Cars with Passengers had left it. Our horses and Carriage were placed upon a rail or trussell and taken part of the way. But the centre of the road had been recently repaired; then made muddy by heavy rains, and was now heaved up by a sharp frost, above the surface of the rail, so that the flange of the wheel had no space at the side of the rail, and was running upon the hard ground— Our horses were taken out of the Rack, but the Carriage was transported onto the place where the Railway crosses the road to Washington 7. Miles from Baltimore. Here Mrs Adams left us and proceeded in her Carriage— Mrremained to see her safely off. The rest of us were on to Ellicott’s Mills in the Car— Several times delayed by Cars freighted with Merchandize meeting us, owing to our being out of time—and by which there was a difficulty in passing. The returning way is not yet finished; so that the Cars in both directions run upon the same rail— They are building the second way upon a foundation of solid granite. I observed not much progress of the work since I viewed it last May, till we came to Ellicott’s Mills, where a high granite bridge of three Arches, is thrown over the stream and the road beyond it. The railway is now continued on the other side, and nearly 12 miles of it are completed— We returned to the half-way-house notwithstanding the impediments which delayed our progress, and before 3. were taken up by the Stage which had left Baltimore at 2. Several passengers were waiting at a neighbouring Inn, having left the Stage while it waited for us, and now rejoined it— Sir William Campbell and I lost our dinners by our ride, but having taken a heavy and oppressive Cold, the loss was to me a salutary privation— Passing by Rossburg, at the dusk of Evening, I saw our Carriage standing at the door— From the time it grew dark the roads were deep and heavy— Soon after 7. in the Evening I alighted at my Son John’s house in Washington, and my wife arrived in the Carriage about an hour later. My Companions in the Stage from Baltimore were dull beyond ordinary Stage-fare, and we were a Coachful of Mutes— We found our Children well, and have cause of gratitude that we ourselves have been preserved unhurt, through a Journey of 500 miles, arduous at this Season, even with all the modern facilities for travelling—
18. V. Saturday— Washington.
Frye Nathaniel Junr.

I arrived here, with a bad Cold and Cough— Of the same character with that which afflicted me the whole of last Winter, and from which I had scarcely recovered when I left Quincy. On rising this morning I had neither fire to warm me, or light enough to write by till day light. I had resumed the reading of the Scriptures yesterday at Barnum’s Hotel, where I found a Bible in our Parlour— This morning I read 1. Chronicles 7.8.9. and sallied forth before daylight for my Morning walk round the Capitol, returning shortly after Sunrise. Met General Jesup, Commodore Patterson and R. Cutts— I asked the General if Mrs Jesup was well: He said no— He had not had his Clothes off the whole Night— On opening my Trunk I found that Neither my Letter Book, nor my Bank Book of the Branch here were with me. Wrote to my Son Charles to ascertain if I had left them at Quincy— Wrote little else; the power of my hand having nearly deserted me— Mr Frye was the only person who called to see me. I received several Letters, and the Certificate under the Seal of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, with the signature of Levi Lincoln, Governor, and of Edward D. Bangs, Secretary, of my election upon the 1st. of November 1830 as a Representative in the Congress of the United States for the Constitutional term, commencing the 4th. of March 1831. The certificate is dated the 13th. instt. The Letter from Mr Monroe which at New-York he mentioned having written to me was little more than an enclosure for a printed copy of the Oration delivered by Mr Gouverneur, at the celebration of the last Revolution in France at New-York— A Letter from Dr Waterhouse chiefly concerning Samuel Adams. A long one from a person signing himself Vetus Miles, complaining of injustice done by Congress in providing for the Revolutionary Officers and men, who had engaged for the war, and not for those whose term of Service was for three years. He seems to suppose me a member of the present Congress— Mrs Adams called upon her brother, and upon Mrs Frye, who is much out of health— My Son John’s children are both unwell, with severe Colds.

19. IV:30— Sunday. Morning service at the Unitarian Church— Heard Mr Cazenove Palfrey now the settled Minister there, from John 6.68 “Then Simon Peter answered him, Lord, to whom shall we go? thou hast the words of eternal Life”— The Sermon was upon the Office and character of Jesus Christ, according to the prevailing Unitarian Doctrines. It was however not controversial—nor very impressive. The singing was remarkably good. Mr Palfrey gave notice that there would be service in the Church on Christmas day. My cold and cough were so troublesome that I could not attend the Evening service— They also disabled me in a great measure from writing. Dr Huntt was here but I did not see him. Mrs W. S. Smith was here in the afternoon, and her husband in the Evening. I received several Letters, still addressed to me as a member of the present Congress. My prospects of doing any thing this Winter, are most discouraging from the state of my health; and with dispositions as earnest and energetic as any that are likely to accrue during my present abode at Washington, I was reduced to waste much of this day in reading the Water-witch, a new novel or Romance by
our Countryman Cooper. Of five or six that he has published, all of high reputation, this is the first that I have undertaken to read— The author is of the School of Sir Walter Scott; and has made himself renowned by painting American Scenery—American manners, and characters—Savage and Colonial; and especially Sailors and Sea-pieces— The men, women and children of this school have a resemblance to nature, as coloured wax figures have to human flesh and blood— If the incidents are marvellous, they are not required to bear the slightest shew of probability. In this work there is a merchant of dutch extraction, Alderman of New-York and smuggler—a Patroon of Kinderhook—a damsel descended from a French Hugonot; and a king-hating Ludlow, who is also Commander of a Queen’s Ship— An old French Valet who prefers Pierre Corneille to Shakespear—and a number of Negroes, all shrewd and sentimental, all clipping English in the same way, and all abstractions without individuality— The mysterious personages Seadrift and Tiller are entirely out of Nature, and the interest of the book is almost wholly concentrated upon them— The dialogue is deficient in simplicity; and among the educated persons often unintelligible— Scott has been the principal reviver of this Style, which had been laughed out of fashion by Moliere, and by the Memoirs of Martinus Scriblerus— The précieux—or the profund—

My cold and cough deprived me of Sleep, and I was obliged to rise soon after three. Read and wrote till six, and then took my walk round the Capitol Square— Visitors, male and female occupied a large portion of the day. The Baron de Sacken is the new Charge d’Affaires from Russia— Mr Hassler is here employed by the Government, upon a comparison of weights and measures. He asked me if there was a certificate, authenticating the collection of Cologne weights, now at the Department of State. I did not at first recollect them—but they were sent by J. M. Forbes from Copenhagen— Hodgson told me that the Treaty with the Porte was now before the Senate. That he himself had been the interpreter of the papers in the Turkish Language. That he expected to be appointed Secretary of a Mission to Constantinople, but it was doubtful whether any person of Rank above a Chargé d’Affaires would be sent. He had applied for the Office of first Dragoman; but Mr Rhind, now here, Commodore Biddle, and Mr Offley had concurred in recommending Mr Navoni, with a Salary of 2500 dollars a year. The Treaty, he said had been concluded in Strict conformity with my autographic Instructions to Crane and Offley—but this does not exactly agree with Mr Matthew L. Davis’s information. He spoke well of Mr Rhind who was aware of the influence which has acted, and will act against us at Constantinople, and who says that the Reis-Effendi received ten thousand Pounds Sterling from the British to defeat the Treaty; but was afterwards deposed at the instance of Count Orloff, Russian Commissioner under the Treaty of Adrianople— General Bernard has obtained a furlough for six Months to visit his friend Genl La Fayette; and is to sail from New-York, on the first of January. He promised to take a Letter from me to General La Fayette— Bernard’s family do not go with him, but I told him he would be wanted there. Mr Vaughan has
been dangerously ill; is yet in very bad health, and expects to return to England in the Spring— Mr Thomas B. Johnson, and Mrs Frye with her Son Thomas were also here. My writing was much interrupted, both by the company, and by my inveterate cough. John’s children are also both unwell with severe Colds.
21. V. Tuesday.

Night sleepless from 1. A.M. There was a light fall of Snow in the Night— And a wintry Northwester succeeded in the morning. When just at the dawn I walked round the Capitol Square, it was sweeping off the Clouds under the sky— After breakfast I walked with my Son John to the house purchased of Daniel Baker. It was then clear, and blowing a gale as of Salt and Nitre. This continued all day and at Night. My cough and hoarseness continue troublesome— I answered the Letter from Samuel L. Southard, received a few days before I left Quincy. After dinner, I was unable to write, and finished reading the Water-witch or Shimmer of the Seas— There is not much inventive faculty required for this species of composition. The author may indulge his imagination without restraint. The delineation of character, the description of Scenery, the percussion flash of moral reflection, and the painting of the Passions constitute the merits of this Class of writers. Their works are not pictures of human life; and are very awkward and incorrect representations of manners. In reading Gilblas I never can divest myself of the idea that he was a real personage, and that his Life and adventures were precisely those related in the book— There is no illusion in the modern Romances. In this book the description of Manhattan Island, Staten Island, Long-Island, the Narrows, the Heights of Neversink, and Long-Island Sound, are proofs of the author’s intimate knowledge of localities, and of an extensive command of language to describe them— The Sea-pieces, the atmospherical phenomena, the chase through Hellgate without Pilots, the battle between the English and French Cruizers; the nocturnal boarding of the English ship by the boats of the French frigate. The destruction of the Corvette by fire, and the escape of the principal dramatis personae upon the raft, are Scenes wrought with great ability and shew the hand of the master— The sweeping off, of the four Officers from the raft, the catastrophe of the man who attempted to take the Shark, The death of the French Captain Dumont and that of the Master Trysail, are described with no inconsiderable pathos; but throughout the whole there is a want of the language of nature. The principal personages are by a narrative and incidents trampling upon all probability brought into situations of extreme danger, and of agonizing horror, but as to the movement of the passions, they all remain in the most imperturbable tranquility. Mr Cooper has great skill in exhibiting physical nature and its operations; but seems not equally conversant with or not equally qualified to portray the more complicated and more intricate movements of the human heart.
22. VI.15. Wednesday.

The Night was severely cold, and Fahrenheit’s Thermometer this morning stood at 8. above 0. The Potowmac river was frozen over, down as low as Alexandria. Yet I took my usual walk round the Capitol, before breakfast— I am endeavouring to resume a habit of Industry, and began but did not finish a Letter to my Son Charles— The day was cold throughout, and I kept the house.
In the Evening I had a visit from Dutee J. Pearce a member of the House of Representatives from Rhode-Island— He spoke of the business transacting in the two Houses of Congress. The house of Representatives are prosecuting before the Senate the Impeachment of James H. Peck Judge of the District Court of the United States in the State of Missouri upon the charge of committing to prison for contempt of Court, and suspending from practice for eighteen Months Edward Luke Lawless an Attorney of the Court— His offence was publishing in a Newspaper at St. Louis strictures which the judge thought contemptuous upon one of his decrees. Pearce said there was a decision this day upon an incidental question shewing that it was a party prosecution— Lawless himself was upon examination; and after answering to a question from the Judge’s Counsel, Mr Wirt, that he was contingently interested in the event of the suit upon which he had criticised the Judge’s decree, declined answering the question to what extent he had been interested— On appeal to the Senate whether he should be required to answer, the decision was 23 to 19 that he should not, by an administration and opposition vote with 2 or 3 exceptions on each side— Pearce spoke of the correspondence said to be pending between President Jackson and Vice-President Calhoun, upon Calhoun’s advice and opinions at the Cabinet Meetings in 1818 upon Jackson’s transactions in Florida during the Seminole War. Pearce has his accounts from Virgil Maxcy a devoted friend of Calhoun’s—a native of Rehoboth Massachusetts—brother of Mr Maxcy sometime President of the Providence College: settled in Maryland, where he has been a member of the Legislature, and Candidate for many Offices; and recently appointed through Calhoun’s influence to the Office of Solicitor of the Treasury created by an Act of the last Congress. Pearce told me the Story of the Correspondence between Jackson and Calhoun, as he had it from Maxcy, and his authority was Calhoun. A version accommodated to Calhoun’s present interest, and false to the extent of pretending that I had in the Cabinet Meetings on the Seminole War concurred with Calhoun and the other members of the Administration in wishing to bring Jackson to a Court of Inquiry, and that Mr Monroe had supported Jackson against us all!
23. V:30. Thursday.

The severity of the cold had somewhat abated this Morning: and the wind was Southerly. I completed my tour round the Capitol Square without much pinching, but my cough continued and my hoarseness and sore throat returned this Evening. My wife has now the same complaint more severely and John’s eldest child Louisa has been confined with it several days, alternately seeming to disappear, and still returning— I finished my Letter to my Son Charles, and wrote one to General La Fayette, to send by Genl. Bernard; being in answer to La Fayette’s Letter to me, of the 8th. of September last— It is somewhat hazardous to express at present opinions upon the recent Revolution in France to one so conspicuous an actor in it as La Fayette. New and great changes there may be expected at no distant period of Time, and while it may be proper to share in the general joy and approbation at the triumph of popular principles over arbitrary power and despotic usurpation, so far as it is yet known to
have proceeded, it is still prudent to rejoice with trembling hope, and anxiously to await the vicissitudes yet to occur, without suffering our eyes to be dazzled with visions of glory which may never be realized— Cheering approbation of the past may be coupled with ardent hope for the future, without extending applause to that which is questionable in principle, or prematurely censuring that which must ultimately be revised— General Van Rensselaer, the Patroon of Albany called upon with his daughter— They are going to pass the Winter at Charleston S. Carolina; proposing to depart to-morrow— Captain Finch of the Navy, with Mr Miller, also paid us visits—Commodores Rodgers and Patterson; and Mrs Tayloe and her daughter Virginia to the Ladies—Mr S. L. Gouverneur of New-York—Mr Bankhead the Secretary and Mr William Pitt Adams an Attaché of the British Legation left Cards. I resumed this Morning the reading of Pliny’s Letters, and read 7 Letters of the third book, though I felt the want of the aids which I possessed at Quincy—the Translation of Orrery, and the Commentary of Longolius. Among these Letters are three of particular interest. One in which he details the daily life of an old man, named Spurinna; whose example he declares it to be his wish and intention to imitate— One, in which he gives an account of his motives for conducting a prosecution against an individual—an Office very odious in that age— And one which is a list of the writings of his Uncle Pliny, the Natural Historian, and a statement of his industry and habits of Study—which are almost incredible and shew what can be effected by firmness and perseverance.
24. VII. Friday.

I received this Morning a Note from General Bernard, to say that he was going for New York, and would receive there any Letter I might wish to send to General La Fayette, until the 1st. of January, when the packet is to sail— His daughter afterwards called, and left word that her father was gone— I wrote to J. P. De Wint— Several Visitors came in the course of the day, and Mr Bailey spent the Evening here— Our house is a hospital of invalids. My cough continues, varying in its symptoms, but no better— A hoarse, sore throat every Night— Lungs loaded with phlegm every Morning— I consulted Huntt, and he advised trash which will teize me and leave me just where I am— Rye mush and Milk for breakfast— A plaster on the breast— Seidlitz Powders and no Suppers— I do not sup— The rest is about as effective as the bread and cheese of Moliere’s Medecin Malgré lui— Huntt said I had once been elected to deliver an Anniversary discourse to the Columbian Institute, and had then declined; with an intimation that I might perform the service at a future day. He was desired to ask if I would undertake it now. I said no—I was deeply sensible to the kindness of the Columbian Institute in re-electing me their President last year. But I had then informed Mr Dickins that I could neither accept the Office nor attend the Meetings of the Society for the present— It might perhaps be otherwise hereafter— But the same state of things continues. It was unnecessary to assign my motives: but should my reasons hereafter cease I shall again attend the Meetings of the Society, and will perform any Office within my ability, which they may assign to me. My reasons are that the principal members of the Administration are now members of the Society. That one of them has acted towards me the part of a wilful and knavish Slanderer.
That two others of them, Berrien and Branch have returned kindness and hospitality from me, with personal disrespect, and dishonourable political malice. I can have no voluntary association with them— Mrs Tudor brought me French Translations of the published biographical notices of her Son, and sent me a Letter from Admiral Roussin to Mrs Stewart and her answer— The Translations and answer are to go by Genl. Bernard— I sent them back this Evening— Mr Bailey was accompanied on his journey from Boston to this City by Mrs Randolph, Mr Jefferson’s daughter who now keeps house here. Her Son in Law Trist is a Clerk in the Department of State—and with his family resides with Mrs Randolph, who has also her three younger daughters with her. Mr Bailey intimated that Mrs Randolph had remarked that neither my wife nor my Son Charles’s wife had visited her at Boston, and that she did not know whether it had been owing to political reasons— Bailey said also that there had been a consultation in the Massachusetts Delegation in which the opinion was unanimous against a Clay National Convention for the present.
25. IV:15. Christmas day— Saturday.

Heard Mr Palfrey from Matthew 1.21 “And she shall bring forth a Son, and thou shalt call his name Jesus; for he shall save his people from their Sins.” The discourse was explanatory—how Jesus should save his people from their Sins according to the Unitarian doctrines— That is, by introducing and establishing an improved system of Morals. After the service I visited Mr Edward Everett at Bernard’s— He has been dangerously ill since his arrival here, and until within two or three days not able to take his Seat in the house of Representatives— Although convalescent his appearance is now far from healthy— While I was with him Mr Letcher of Kentucky, Mr Vance of Ohio and G. S. Bulfinch came in. The accounts from Ohio and Kentucky are not so favourable to Mr Clay’s prospects as had been anticipated. It is ascertained that his friend J. J. Crittenden cannot be elected to the Senate of the United States— Probably he himself, if set up as a Candidate by his friends would not be more successful. The chance is that Rowan will be re-elected; and the last resource of Mr. Clay’s friends is to endeavour to postpone the Election till the next Session of the Legislature—that is to send back the Question to the People, and the Chapter of accidents— As I was returning home, I met almost at my door Coll. H. W. Dwight who came in and sat half an hour with me— I then paid my visit to my neighbours Mrs Tudor and Mrs Stewart. We had invited Mrs and Mr Frye—Mr T. B. Johnson, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith to dine with us; but they were all this day indisposed and not one of them came. I myself was more unwell than I have been for several years—suffering in addition to my racking cough, a very severe toothache, and symptoms of fever. My wife the two children, and others of the family were likewise unwell, and our Christmas was much more like a fast than a festival— My abstinence gave me no present relief— Mr Joseph M. White the delegate from Florida in the house of Representatives was here in the Evening— A bookseller of the City had advertised for Sale a copy of Evelyn’s Sylva, of the last Edition of 1825. in two Quarto Volumes— I sent immediately and purchased it, but the bookseller sent me word that Mr White was at present using one of the Volumes of the work, and wished to retain it a day or two— White himself confirmed this and I desired him to keep the Volumes as
long as he should have occasion for them— Mr White mentioned to me, that in the Reports from the Navy Department at this Session of Congress it is announced, that after the present year the Plantations of Live-Oaks in Florida, which I had commenced, and which are now in a very flourishing State will be abandoned and broken up; on the allegation that along the whole Coast of Florida, and of Georgia, nature produces the Live Oak in so great abundance, that an artificial Plantation can be of no use there. This, White says is an egregious misrepresentation, and is contradicted by a mass of testimony upon which I commenced the Plantation— There are now he says seventy thousand trees on the ground set apart for it by my direction, requiring an expense not exceeding seven thousand dollars to maintain and which will now be abandoned to perish, or come to nothing.— He wishes to have the Plantation established by a special Act of Congress, and not to depend on the discretion of the Executive, and was now consulting Evelyn, for facts which would aid his argument. He asked me to write on the subject, but I thought it would be useless at present— I advised him to consult Du Hamel upon Plantations as well as Evelyn— I received a Letter from R. Walsh jr. asking me likewise to write upon the Message and the Colonial question— Wrote a short Letter to Charles— Sick family.
26. V:30. Sunday.

Painful, Sleepless and feverish Night— But much relieved from the tooth ache, and feverish head ache— Heard Mr Palfrey from John 14.28. “My father is greater than I.” A regular controversial discourse upon the inferiority of Christ to the father, in which most of the texts relied upon as supporting the doctrine of the divinity of Christ were discussed; and those which decidedly mark the superiority of the father cited and dwelt upon. After Church I had visits from Mr Swann the District Attorney and Mr Daniel Brent— Mr Wirt who was attending as the principal Counsel of Judge Peck before the Senate, was called home to Baltimore by the illness of his youngest daughter, Agnes, who had the Scarlet fever. Mr Brent Spoke of the Treaty with Turkey, now before the Senate, and said it was very doubtful whether it would be ratified. That it was very loosely drawn up, and had in it a secret Article of the import mentioned to me by Matthew L. Davis but one which in the French language was susceptible of a construction which placed the United States upon a less favourable footing in the Turkish dominions, than other Nations which had Treaties with the Porte— That Commodore Biddle and Mr Offley had both warmly protested against this Article, and had assigned their Reasons for the protest: declaring that they signed the Treaty with great reluctance, on Account of this Article. It is remarkable that my Instructions to Offley and Crane had expressly forbidden their assent to any Article, incompatible with the neutrality of the United States—and expressly cautioned them against equivocations of Translation in the use of the Languages— Mr Everett was here this Evening— I answered Mr Walsh’s Letter, and declined writing for publication upon the President’s Message, and upon the Colonial Trade question— The time for writing upon these subjects has not yet arrived— Whether it will ever come is far from certain. The attempt to direct public opinion is always hazardous—often desperate—and the moment to act must be waited for with untiring Patience, and seized with instinctive sagacity— Preparation for it however would be useful—and that I shall neglect. I have begun writing with the intention of employing my time to some purpose this Winter— But there is an arrear in this diary from the close of November to fill up, before I can think of any thing else and I began upon it this Morning— I read two
or three Letters of the third book of Pliny’s Epistles— The 7th. to Caninius begins with announcing the death of Silius Italicus, by voluntary starvation— Cicero’s friend Atticus had died in the same manner— It appears to have been an act not uncommon among the antient Romans— Pliny then gives a character of Silius Italicus rather equivocal— He had disgraced himself by voluntary prosecutions in the time of Nero— Since that time his conduct had been more creditable— He had devoted his times to Poetry, and the cultivation of the fine Arts— The Letter closes with reflections on the lapse of time and the vicissitudes of Life— I read also Lord Byron’s Tragedy of Sardanapalus.
27. V:15. Monday.

Rainy Night and Morning. The symptoms of my cough are constantly varying, and have threatened to disable me from writing altogether. But having yesterday undertaken the recovery of my arrears in this Diary, I devote 12 days to that work exclusively; allowing a remnant only for writing an occasional Letter. Postponed my walk round the Capitol Square from the Morning before breakfast, to the afternoon before dinner. I read part of the Article in the American Quarterly Review of this Month, upon Banks and Currency— It was written by Mr Gallatin; with great ability— I received this morning by the Mail a Newspaper called the Miners and Farmer’s Journal. dated 22.
