Novr 1830. and published at Charlotte, Mecklenburg County, North-Carolina— It contains an Article purporting to be taken from the Yadkin and Catawba Journal, signed by Joseph M’Knitt Alexander; and headed: Declaration of Independence, by the Citizens of Mecklenburg County (then including Cabarrus) North-Carolina, on the 20th. day of May 1775— The paper is directed in manuscript to me: headed Proofs of Declaration of Independence By Mecklenburg, No. Carolina May 20. 1775. Also by Legislature of No. Carolina on 12. May 1776. And at the bottom of the first page of the paper is written— “As Mr Jefferson’s denial of the above transactions comes to us through a Correspondence with your father—it is hoped this will be received and used with that comity with which it is transmitted by your friend &c. J. M. Alexander.”— This refers to a Letter from T. Jefferson to my father dated 9. July 1819. and published in the late Edition of Jefferson’s writings. Vol. 4. p. 314. This Mecklenburg Declaration of Independence had already been asserted in several Newspapers— Jefferson cites the Essex Register of 22 June 1819. but wonders that it had escaped the attention of the Richmond Enquirer and of the National Intelligencer. He treats the whole Story as a fraudulent fabrication, and unjustifiable Quiz— This paper purports to be a reply to Mr Jefferson’s Letter— It refers to a pamphlet published by Gales at Raleigh in 1822. and to a number of certificates from various persons, but does not give the certificates themselves. The Statement is that two persons delegated from each Militia Captain’s Company in the County of Mecklenburg, met at Charlotte, on the 19th of May 1775. and with many other persons on the next day issued this Declaration of Independence, drawn up by a Dr Ephraim Brevard; with sundry other Resolutions, all which were sent by Captain James Jack to Congress— That Jack did accordingly deliver them to the Delegates from North-Carolina in Congress, Caswell and Hooper, by whom they were communicated to Congress; not officially; because that was thought to be premature. But Jack was assured they were approved by Congress
28. IV:30. Tuesday. Sun rose VII.21.

Morning walk round the capitol Square— Paid visits to Mr Roux de Rochelle and Mr Vaughan Ministers from France and Great-Britain—Mrs Frye—T. B. Johnson—Barons Sacken and Stackelberg, and Mr Bankhead— Mr Roux de Rochelle arrived here last Summer as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from Charles the 10th. king of France—very soon after his arrival the revolution of 29. July expelled Charles 10 from the throne of France— Mr Roux floated with the tide—acknowledged allegiance to the new Government, and received new Credentials from Louis Philippe, which he presented to the President and was received— By the last Accounts from France it appears that he has been already superseded by Mr Serrurier who was Minister from France here during our last War with Great Britain, and at the time of the fall of Napoleon— Mr Roux has been many years a subaltern in the Department of foreign Affairs— His Son was Secretary to the Legation; and he brought with him his wife, and a large Collection of Pictures of the French and Italian Schools— He told me that Mr Sears of Boston and his family were Passengers with them in the vessel in which they came from France— Neither Mr Roux nor any one of his family Speak of our Language— I had declined an invitation to dine with Mr Vaughan on Christmas day. I had now some Conversation with him upon the recent accounts from England, which are indicative of great vicissitudes, and portend mighty Revolutions. The Duke of Wellington and his Administration have fallen; and a whig Ministry at the head of which is Earl Grey have taken their places— The House of Commons, the Church, and the National debt are to be the first objects of reform. The king and Queen, with the Cabinet Ministers were to have been present at the dinner at Guildhall on Lord Mayor’s day—9. November. But two days before, the Lord Mayor wrote a Letter to the Duke of Wellington, advising him not to come, unless very strongly guarded; for that there was a design to raise a mob and to attack his person— This Letter was read by Sir Robert Peel, in the House of Commons where the information of the intended personal attack upon the Duke of Wellington was observed— The king, royal family and Ministers did not attend the Lord Mayor’s feast— There were Riots, but not of much importance— A week after in the House of Commons, on the motion to go into a Committee of supply, there was a majority of 30 votes against the Ministers; all of whom the next day resigned— The new Ministers come in pledged to bring forward a plan for a reform in Parliament— I wrote this Evening to Dr Waterhouse— Mr T. B. Johnson and Mrs W. S. Smith were here.
29. VI. Wednesday.

Notwithstanding the continuance of my Cough, I walk round the Capitol Square every morning before breakfast, and generally before Sunrise, excepting when confined to the house by rain. Visit from Mr Vance, a member of the House of Representatives from the State of Ohio, and in the Evening from Mrs Tudor, who brought three Packets for General Bernard at New-York which I forwarded— Further Accounts were this day received from Europe. Vance said that some of the friends of General Jackson were speaking of the downfal of the Military Administration in England—upon which he told them he heartily wished the Military administration in this Country would follow their example—and their king too. In France there has been also more than one change of Ministry— And the convulsion
in the Netherlands has completely separated the two parts of that Kingdom. It appears to be impossible that this event should pass off without producing a general War in Europe— The movements in the Catholic Netherlands all tend to the ultimate reunion of that Country with France— Geographically, Historically, by Language, and Religion, they properly belong to France— They enjoyed the benefits of that Union, for twenty years from the battle of Gemmapes till the overthrow of Napoleon, when by the general parcelling out of Europe at the Congress of Vienna, they were united with the old Dutch Republic to form a kingdom for the house of Orange— The king of the Netherlands is a Man of good intentions, moderate abilities, and indefatigable devotion to his duties— His Government throughout his dominions has been patriotic and paternal. The revolt has not been so much against him, as against the unnatural Union into which the Belgians were forced by the Congress of Vienna— And the result shews that the Union of men under one Government, must be held together by natural ties or by military despotism— The disruption of the kingdom of the Netherlands was the immediate and inevitable consequence of the Revolution in France— The king of the Netherlands, sustained by his Batavian subjects and army, but deserted by the Belgian portion of his troops, after a few feeble, and ineffectual military Struggles and Proclamations had acknowledged the Independence of the Belgian Provinces, as have the five European Allies of the Congress of Vienna. But they have forbidden the Belgians to constitute a Republic and have recommended to them a Sovereign of the House of Nassau— The Belgian provisional Government have agreed to adopt a limited Monarchy for their Government; but have excluded forever the house of Orange from the throne— Meanwhile Russia, Austria and Prussia are raising armies by the hundred thousand. France is doing the same, and Até hot from Hell already shews her face— There is a premature rancour by the accounts this day received that the Emperor of Russia has declared War against France— I believe it impossible that the ensuing year should pass over without a War in Europe.
30. V:30. Thursday.

Morning walk round the Capitol Square. I received visits from Mr Burrows of New-York, and from Mr Vaughan the British Minister. Burrows told me that he came here to see if he could not prevail upon Congress to pass the bill now before them in favour of Mr Monroe— Ten or eleven years ago, Burrows being then barely of age, was employed I believe as a bearer of despatches to Sweden. I heard nothing of him from that time till some two or three years since the Newspapers gave notice, that Mr Burrows had generously lent a thousand dollars to Mr Monroe, to enable him with his family to visit his daughter at New-York. About four Months since, the Corvette which Baron Krudener had purchased for the Emperor of Russia, having sailed from New-York with the Baron on board was overtaken by a Gale or Hurricane, which made her a perfect wreck. In this condition, she was picked up, by a vessel belonging to Mr Burrows and brought
back to New-York. For the Service rendered on that occasion Mr Burrows declined receiving any compensation—in consequence of which, by the direction of the President, a Letter was written to Mr Burrows by Mr Van Buren presenting to him the thanks of the Government of the United States for this signal instance of humanity and disinterested magnanimity— Mr Burrows said it was well known he was for Mr Clay for next President of the United States, and he fully believed the whole electoral vote of the State of New-York would be for Clay— That on his arrival here he immediately received an invitation to a private dinner at the Presidents and had dined with him yesterday— That he was to dine this day with Mr Van Buren; who had also sent him a card of invitation from Mr Vaughan to his Ball to-morrow, and Mrs Van Buren had invited him to go with him in his Carriage— But he was not to be bought, and he had expressed his Sentiments so freely to the President that he told him he was the most Independent man he had seen since he was President— Last week Captain Law the Collector of the Port of New London was removed and a man from New-Hampshire appointed in his place— Burrows said he had told the President it was the most unpopular act he had ever done— That Law was a man of most respectable character; universally beloved, an old Revolutionary Officer, and one of the very few survivors from the old Jersey Prison ship— The President told him that he had been prevailed upon to remove Captain Law, at the unanimous and earnest representations of all the friends of the Administration in New Hampshire but that he would give him another Office better than the one he had taken from him. Burrows spoke of a line of communication which he had established by regular packets from New-York to Carthagena. From thence to Chagres, and thence across the Isthmus to Panama— Also of his having volunteered to give bond for Samuel Swartwout, when he was appointed Collector, at New-York, and could not otherwise have made up the amount of bonds required by Law; and could not have held the Office. Swartwout had refused to remove any of the friends of the last Administration from their places in the Custom house, and last week was attacked for this forbearance in Mr Van Burens paper the New-York Courier and Enquirer. He wished me to speak to J. W. Taylor in behalf of Mr Monroe, which I promised to do, and said he had persuaded Mr Mallary of Vermont to support the Bill—but that the great difficulty was with the members from Virginia— Mr Vaughan brought a couple of Vials of black drops which he had received from England— I returned the visits of Mr J. D. Dickinson and B. O. Tayloe, of J. W. Taylor and Vance—Matthew L. Davis and Gouverneur; only the last of whom I found at his lodgings— With him were Marshal Ringgold Mr Ward formerly a member of Congress from the State of New York, and also a member elect of the next Congress from the District of Sleepy Hollow as he said— There was also a Mr Magennis from Missouri, one of the witnesses on the trial now before the Senate of judge Peck, and as I perceived a willing witness against him— I called at the shop of W. J. Stone the Engraver to enquire concerning a copper-plate which I wish to have engraved. He shewed me a number of complicated machines of his own invention, for the exercise of his art as an Engraver; also collections of precious Stones and of Minerals which he said he had imported from Heidelberg in Germany; all proving his ingenuity, and his turn to philosophical enquiries— Stone is an English Artist, whom I employed much, while I was in the
department of State, and who engraved the fac-simile of the Declaration of Independence— With Mrs Adams I attended this Evening a Concert by Mrs Knight, at the Unitarian Church— She sang “Comfort ye my People”—and “Angels ever bright and fair”—remarkably well— Mrs Franklin’s “Let the bright Seraphim” was less succesful— The company was very thin—not exceeding 30 persons.
31. IV:30: Friday

Warm and sultry— Rain with Thunder and Lightening shortly after I rose. It appeared to pass off, and as if clearing up— Before Sunrise I took my walk round the Capitol Square, but before reaching home was overtaken by a very heavy thunder shower— Being near Barnard’s Hotel I took shelter in Mr Everett’s Apartment, and found him just risen— I desired him to inform his brother Alexander that Mr William Tudor’s Journals and other Manuscripts having been very voluminous I had been obliged to leave them at Quincy; and should therefore not be able to prepare the Article upon his life for the April number of the North American Review: but as it was my intention to return early in the Spring to Quincy I hoped to have it ready for the July number— The French Minister Roux de Rochelle with his wife and Son, paid us a morning visit but Mrs Adams was confined to her chamber and unable to receive the Lady. I was engaged all the remainder of the day in writing—

Day. The first week of the month I was occupied at Quincy in preparing for my departure for this place— The next ten days was upon the road travelling hither—and the last fortnight having been resuming my habits of idle industry with a severe cold and cough upon me the whole time— My hour of rising has been irregular from half past three to seven; sleepless Nights having been followed by others of longer than my usual term of repose— This Diary had run in arrear from the close of the last Month until Christmas day— Undertaking since then to retrieve those arrears I have been able to do scarcely any thing else; and have another week of the same labour before me— We breakfast between nine and ten— Dine at four and my usual hour for retiring to bed is from ten to eleven— I now read very little of any thing, and spend from six to eight hours of every day in writing— My only exercise is a walk round the Capitol Square which according to the state of the weather I take before breakfast or before dinner. A small portion of time is engaged in receiving and returning visits.

The year has past away— I close it with gratitude to a kind Providence for the numerous enjoyments it has brought with it. Humbled in Spirit but resigned for those which it has denied; and with keen self disapprobation for the time which has been wasted and irretrievably lost. May the future be more profitable!
